Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Cross-language Interactions in Beginning Adult Bilinguals

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The United States lags far behind other countries in terms of foreign language success rates, which has far-reaching implications for our engagement, safety, and growth in an increasingly global world. One reason for this lag might be that American students are first introduced to a second language relatively late, often not until high school or college. Learning a second language at these ages can be quite challenging, in part because of the extensive linguistic knowledge that young adults already have in their native language. The goal of the present research is to better understand how different types of native language knowledge influence second language word learning: How does the native language help or hinder second language word learning in young adults and why? Understanding these interactions will further our understanding of how the new second language words are represented in the brain and how they are connected up to the existing linguistic system. The extent to which involvement of the native language differs as a function of learning methodology will also be tested. These studies will help form the foundation for the development of more effective, evidence-based foreign language teaching practices.

More specifically, the proposed studies use event-related potentials (ERPs) to track second language word learning among monolingual college students in a laboratory setting. ERPs measure the electrical activity of the brain on a millisecond-by-millisecond basis, which makes them useful for tracking how rapid word recognition processes unfold over time. The focus is on two specific types of native language words and how their relative importance changes over learning time. Aim 1 considers how newly learned second language words (e.g., lait is the French word for 'milk') interact with the mental representations of neighboring native language words (e.g., laid, last), which overlap in form. Aim 2 considers the connections between the second language word representations (e.g., lait) and their native language translation equivalents (e.g., milk), which overlap in meaning. Both types of words play prominent roles in theoretical models of second language learning and processing; however, their specific roles differ substantially across models. Thus, the field is in need of empirical evidence that will adjudicate between these various models and advance our understanding of how newly learned words are integrated with the native language lexicon. Understanding the neurocognitive mechanisms of second language word learning is a prerequisite to developing evidence-based teaching practices and improving foreign language outcomes among young adult students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Young adults who begin learning a second language already have a wealth of linguistic information that can be transferred from their native language. The primary goal of this project was to better understand how this native language knowledge can help or hinder late acquisition of a second language, with a focus on written words. Understanding these interactions between languages is fundamental for developing comprehensive theories regarding the neurocognitive mechanisms that underlie second language learning. In turn, this theoretical foundation contributes to the broader goal of this line of research, which is to form an evidence base that can be used to improve how second languages are taught in the United States. 

Over the course of this award, we focused on the influence of different areas of pre-existing linguistic knowledge. For instance, we examined the nuances of visual word processing and the extent to which these processes can be carried over from the native language to a second language. We found, both in laboratory learners of an artificial language and in more proficient late English-Spanish bilinguals that word recognition differs across languages, perhaps as a result of having more exposure to native language words. This work has implications for theories of visual word recognition. It suggests that there may be different ways to represent a visual word. Using the optimal pathway requires substantial exposures to the word, well beyond what is required for episodic learning.

We also examined how visual word learning in a second language is influence by pre-existing phonological knowledge. Phonology refers to the sounds of a language. In a comprehensive and novel review of the literature, we found that individuals who have stronger phonological skills in their native language perform better on measures of visual word learning. This may contribute to the wide variability across individuals in terms of second language learning outcomes. Teaching phonology along with the visual words also appears to burst learning outcomes, reinforcing the connections across modalities.

Finally, we examined the integrated network structure of the lexicon by teaching participants words from an artificial second language that had different relationships. In one study, we compared acquisition of words that had English translations with many versus few English neighbors. Neighbors refer to the number of words of the same length that can be achieved by changing only one letter. In a subsequent study, we compared acquisition of words in an artificial second language that had many neighbors in that language (e.g., plusk, plusm, plesm) or not (e.g., griph). Participants were able to type the words with more neighbors more accurately than those with no neighbors, especially early during learning. This provides preliminary evidence for improved learning outcomes when words that are similar to one another are taught simultaneously.

Overall, this multi-pronged approach to investigating second language learning in young adults has contributed several important findings that have informed theoretical models of visual word recognition, learning, and bilingualism. We were also successful at providing some insight into how the empirical study of language learning can be translated into more effective instructional practices. Much remains to be done in this regard to ensure that theoretical advances continue to be communicated to a wider audience and translated into improving classroom outcomes.
